Secondly, the relation of the law of inheritance or succession to the classifioetion so far suggested is by no means clear. lf, however, we ask what is comprised in the idea of an inhesitance, the reply must be, the relations ol the deceased person in the departments of ownership and obliga· tion, or. as the Romans significantly expressed it, his universitas iuris; his successor takes his property, and has to pay his debts The law of succession is thus a division of the law of property, but its importance in all legal systema forbids our making it a merely subor- dinate division. Rather, we should divide the latter into simultaneous and successive property law; the former comprising the law of things and the law of obligations, the latter the law of inheritance.

The field of private law then comprises five great departments :-

ἰ. Pure family law, including marriage, parental power, kinship, and the relation of guardian and ward.

ii. Applied family law.

iii. The law ol' things, under its three main heads os owncrship, possession, and iura in re aliena.

iv. The law of obligations.

v. The law ol inheritance.
